title: Hi-Tech Innovation News - Information Technology, Inventions News

items.title: New diode chain could be used to develop high-power terahertz technologies

Bubble wrap bursts enable power-free acoustic testing
Laser can transform complex semiconductor properties in single-step process
Is your ultra-HD TV worth it? Scientists measure the resolution limit of the human eye
DeepMind introduces AI agent that learns to complete various tasks in a scalable world model
Harnessing disorder: Metamaterials researchers achieve static mechanical cloaking and camouflage
Turning pollution into clean fuel with stable methane production from carbon dioxide
Minimal pixels achieve the highest possible resolution visible to the human eye
Novel carbon nanotube-based transistors reach THz frequencies
Secret QR codes and hidden warnings: 3D printing technique allows precise control of material properties, point by point
Semi-transparent solar cells achieve record efficiency to advance building-integrated photovoltaics
Nanoporous silicon harvests electricity from water friction
items.summary:
- **IE-TENG** harnesses pressure-driven intrusion–extrusion of water in hydrophobic nanoporous silicon to generate electricity at the solid–liquid interface, achieving up to **9%** efficiency.
- The device is designed to be conductive, nanoporous, and scalable, enabling autonomous, maintenance-free sensors and wearables powered by water.
- Using common materials (silicon and water), this approach could enable self-sustaining energy sources for sensing and robotics.

items.title: New organic thin-film tunnel transistors for wearable and other small electronics
Scientists create a novel hydrogel for unclonable security tags
Software designs eco-friendly clothing that can reassemble into new items
Six-stack CMOS sets record for large-area electronics
items.summary:
- KAUST researchers achieved the first *six-stack hybrid CMOS* for large-area electronics, setting a new benchmark in integration density and efficiency. 
- The fabrication stayed under *150°C* and proceeded at *nearly room temperature*, with improvements in surface smoothness and *vertical stacking* alignment. 
- This advance could accelerate *flexible electronics*, *smart health*, and the *Internet of Things*, enabling more power in less space.

items.title: 'Wetware': Scientists use human mini-brains to power computers
From stiff to soft in a snap: Magnetic jamming opens new frontiers for microrobotics
Shapeshifting soft robot uses electric fields to swing like a gymnast
Metabots reshape from flat sheets into hundreds of forms
items.summary:
- Metabots are thin sheets with films that respond to electricity or magnetic fields, enabling *shape-shifting* into hundreds of stable configurations.
- By linking multiple sheets, a metabot can lie flat or fold into many states to move, jump, crawl, or grip objects.
- This *proof-of-concept* work shows a cheap, adaptable path bridging metamaterials and robotics with potential for reconfigurable devices.

items.title: A stapler that knows when you need it: Using AI to turn everyday objects into proactive assistants
Prototype battery powered by glucose and vitamin B2 offers path to more affordable energy storage
Laser-tuned polymer surface switches between cooling and heating modes without consuming electricity
How a fabric patch uses static electricity in your clothes to let you chat with AI and control smart devices
Self-healing layer improves the safety and lifespan of all-solid-state lithium batteries
Soft-to-rigid artificial muscle lifts 4,000× weight
items.summary:
- A UNIST team created a *soft artificial muscle* that stiffens under load and softens during contraction, enabling both strength and flexibility. 
- Weighing 1.25 g, it can lift about 5 kg (≈4,000× its weight) and reach 86.4% strain with a work density of 1,150 kJ/m³. 
- The device uses a *dual cross-linked polymer* with *magnetic particles*; external magnetic fields enable precise actuation for *soft robots* and *wearables*.

items.title: This digital hand enables hands-free virtual reality
MXene current collectors could reduce size and improve recyclability of Li-ion batteries
Biohybrid leaf mimics photosynthesis to turn CO₂ and sunlight into useful chemicals
Prototype LED as thin as wallpaper can glow like the sun
items.summary:
- Researchers created a **paper-thin QLED**—only tens of nanometers thick, akin to *wallpaper*—that emits a *sun-like* full-spectrum white light using a tuned mix of red, yellow-green and blue *quantum dots*.
- Built on indium tin oxide with conductive polymers and metal oxides, devices operate at modest voltages (8–11.5 V), achieve over **92% color rendering**, and reduce blue output to be more *eye- and sleep-friendly*.
- The prototype promises *eye-friendly lighting*, adaptive displays and horticulture use, but remains at the development stage before broad commercial deployment.

items.title: 'Chinese lantern' structure shifts into more than a dozen shapes for various applications
Light-controlled electron gas for ultra-fast electronics
items.summary:
- Researchers generated an *optically induced high-mobility electron gas* at oxide interfaces (infinite-layer nickelate/SrTiO3), creating a reversible light‑switchable conducting layer.
- Light control promises **ultra‑fast, energy‑efficient** electronics — for example, light-controlled transistors that could remove ~1/3 of chip electrical contacts and optical detectors with up to 100,000× stronger current.
- Achieved via atomic-scale interface engineering, experiments and modeling and published in *Nature Materials*, this advance could impact *spintronics* and *quantum computing*.

items.title: Scientists create world's first chip that combines 2D materials with conventional silicon circuitry
High-performance supercapacitor made from upcycled water bottles
3D printing method 'grows' intricate, ultra-strong materials inside water-based gel
Thin solar-powered films purify water by killing bacteria even in low sunlight
Concrete 'battery' now packs 10 times the power
Kirigami parachute suitable for humanitarian missions stabilizes quickly and doesn't pitch
Engineers create first artificial neurons that could directly communicate with living cells
Light-triggered process lets 3D printers create custom glass structures without glue or high temperatures
Tiny explosions and soft materials make onscreen braille more robust
Gesture PINs: NFC enables shimmy-and-shake authentication
items.summary:
- *NFCGest* uses changes in *NFC* radio signals caused by nine card-holding *gestures* (swipes, taps, etc.) to input a PIN or pick a tip, with a custom AI reaching *~92% accuracy*.
- The upgrade is cheap (under *$20* per terminal), promising faster, contactless interactions that improve accessibility and reduce surface touch.
- Presented at UIST 2025 and being patented by UBC, the approach needs broader testing and payment-terminal integration before wide deployment.
